content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this solution because it correctly parses each line to extract the topic and its starting page, then performs a single linear pass to find the chapter whose starting page ≤ p and whose successor’s starting page > p, printing that topic; if p is beyond the last chapter’s start, it falls through the loop and prints the last topic. This matches the problem’s guarantees (chapters in order, strictly increasing page numbers, and p ≥ first chapter’s page), runs in O(n) time and O(n) space, and handles all provided edge cases (p exactly on a chapter start, p between chapters, and p after the final chapter). The simple split()-based parsing is sufficient given the fixed input format, and the for/else construct neatly covers the “after last chapter” case.
For parsing any language with a split() method/function should be sufficient
It took me 8 minutes in Python so I can't quite approve it but it feels like the right level of difficulty for a CoC to me. Will upvote it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I solved it in 13LOCs, I think that should be doable in the aloted time.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I refuse this contribution because the input is a bit complex for parsing stuff

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: For me, I think this puzzle is a great puzzle with no errors. Maybe consider removing it from reverse, as I don't think anyone will understand this without the instructions. Thanks for your contribution!

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I found the parsing to be too difficult for Clash of Code. Thank you for your time and energy and take care.

Title
* Consider changing the title, as a puzzle with the same name already exists: https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/table-of-contents

Input
* Please rename "[[n]]", as it's also used for individual chapter numbers.

Stub generator
* Line 1: Please replace "n" (see the previous point).

Output
* Please clarify that the output should be [[theTopic]] of page [[p]].

Constraints
* Please add "[[pageNumber]], " before "[[p]]".

* Please add the following constraints:
  • [[p]] ≥ [[pageNumber]] of Chapter 1.

  • [[theTopic]] contains English letters and digits only.

  • All of [[theTopic]]s are distinct.

Cases
* Test 1: Please change 4 to a greater number.

* Validator 1: Please revise [[p]] to 2, which is part of Chapter 1, similar to Test 1.

* Validator 3: Please change 96 to a 3-digit number and update [[p]] to a larger 3-digit number.

* Test 4: Please change "64813" to "4813".

* Test 4: Please revise [[p]] to a 5-digit number between 10000 and 89999, similar to Validator 4.

* Please add a pair of cases which satisfy all these conditions:
  • At least 7 chapters.
  • At least 3 of [[theTopic]]s contain [[p]] as a substring (at least one for each: at the start, middle, and end), but none of them is the expected output.
  • [[p]] is a 4-digit number and the same as [[pageNumber]] of one of the chapters (not the first two or last two).

* Please add a pair of cases which satisfy all these conditions:
  • At least 2 chapters.
  • [[pageNumber]] of the last chapter is a 1-digit number.
  • [[p]] is 1,000,000.

* Please add a pair of cases which satisfy all these conditions:
  • At least 7 chapters.
  • All [[theTopic]]s are random integers (no letters), each 7 to 10 digits long.
  • [[p]] is a 6-digit number that is exactly *one less* the [[pageNumber]] of one of the chapters (not the first two or last two).

* Please add a pair of cases where the table of contents contains 1 chapter only.

Thanks.

I have to disagree with you on that point.
In Python this is all you need to parse a line:
 s = input()
    tokens = s.split()
    title = tokens[2]
    page_number=int(tokens[5])

Overall I found the challenge pleasant and not too difficult, but just with enough twist to be original. While I didn't time myself, my first try solution came at 13 LOCs.
Bro, this puzzle is so easy.

Goal / Input / Output / Constraints
* Consider changing "[[theTopic]]" to "[[topic]]".

Constraints
* Please add "≤ [[x]]" after "[[n]]".

Cases
* Test 4: Please revise [[p]] to a 5-digit number between 10000 and 89999, similar to Validator 4.

* Test 6: The word "Page" is missing in the table of contents.

* Validator 6: Same comment as Test 6.

* Test 7: Page numbers in the table of contents should not exceed 1,000,000.

* Validator 7: Same comment as Test 7.

Thanks.
